Synopsis: 
While doing more in Brooklyn, New York, the young Tommy Poper just waiting the moment, as he stands on tiptoe standing to reach a radio amateur, can speak with his father, traveling the world, years later, Tommy and Mr. Popper's (Jim Carrey), a successful real estate developer in Manhattan. After going through an amicable divorce with Amanda (Carla Gugino), with two children (Madeline Carroll and Maxwell Perry Cotton) whom he meets every two weekends, Mr. Popper leads a life of luxury at the ultra modern apartment Park Avenue, while doing very well on your way to becoming a member of the prestigious firm he works for. That is, until one morning a large packaging appears at his door, one last gift from his late father, a memory of Antarctica. 

Inside the wooden box, tucked between ice packs, a penguin is 60 cm tall, with bright orange legs and all. Not a toy penguin, not a stuffed bird for a taxidermist, as is Mr. Popper at first, but a real penguin, alive and kicking, it scampers across the floor while emitting strong Poper squawking. Eager to get rid of this wild creature, Popper makes contact with each and every imaginable city and state agencies, but none is willing to take on a pet penguin. Your call to the Antarctic to try to send the penguin back fails and ends up causing the arrival of five other penguins at the door of Popper. 

As you begin to make friends, and more and more involved with peers winged apartment life quickly starts to freak out Poper: the flamboyant New York apartment becomes a winter wonderland, the contract that has long been working derailed and almost did not end up in jail. But thanks to his new duties, Poper begins to understand the importance of family, human and less human. 

Production notes: 
Adaptation of the text child of Richard and Florence Atwater is first published in 1938.
